NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR SEOUL | NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR SEOUL (Reuters) - North Korea reiterated on Saturday that it would not give up its nuclear weapons, rejecting a U.S. condition for talks although it said it was willing to discuss disarmament. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR North Korea, in a sign of a possible end to weeks of heightened hostility on the Korean peninsula, offered the United States and South Korea a list of conditions on Thursday for talks, including the lifting of U.N. sanctions. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But the United States said it was awaiting "clear signals" that North Korea would halt its nuclear weapons activities. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The U.S. should not think about the denuclearization on the peninsula before the world is denuclearized," the North's state-run Rodong Sinmun newspaper said in a commentary. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "There may be talks between the DPRK and the U.S. for disarmament but no talks on denuclearization," it said. North Korea's official name is the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK). NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR North Korea signed a denuclearization-for-aid deal in 2005 but later backed out of that pact. It now says its nuclear arms are a "treasured sword" that it will never give up. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It conducted its third nuclear test in February. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The test triggered new U.N. sanctions which in turn led to a dramatic intensification of North Korea's threats of nuclear strikes against South Korea and the United States. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry visited China, South Korea and Japan this month for talks on North Korea and stressed his interest in a diplomatic solution to the tension on the peninsula. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He later told a U.S. Senate hearing that North Korea's list of conditions was "at least a beginning gambit", but added that it was "not acceptable, obviously, and we have to go further". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Rodong Sinmun said U.S. talk of dialogue was "nothing but rhetoric". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR North Korea has a long record of making threats to secure concessions from the United States and South Korea, only to repeat the process later. Both the United States and the South have said in recent days that the cycle must cease. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR (Reporting by Robert Birsel; Editing by Sanjeev
